verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:1
verses.text: Letter XXI.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:3
verses.text: Ambrose excuses himself for not having gone to the consistory when summoned, on the ground that in matters of faith no one but bishops could rightly judge, and that he was not contumacious because he would not suffer wrong to be done to his own order.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:4
verses.text: And he adds that Auxentius would perhaps choose as judges either Jews or unbelievers, that is, persons hostile to Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:5
verses.text: He says further that he is willing to discuss the matters in dispute at a synod, and that he would have told the Emperor by word of mouth what he is now writing, but that his fellow bishops and the people would not suffer him to do so.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:6
verses.text: Ambrose, Bishop, to the most gracious Emperor and blessed Augustus, Valentinian.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:8
verses.text: Dalmatius, the tribune and notary, summoned me by the orders of your Clemency, as he asserted, demanding that I should also choose judges, as Auxentius had done.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:9
verses.text: He did not mention the names of those who had been asked for, but he added that there was to be a discussion in the consistory, and that the judgment of your piety would give the decision.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:11
verses.text: To this I make, as I think, a suitable answer.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:12
verses.text: No one ought to consider me contumacious when I affirm what your father of august memory not only replied by word of mouth, but also sanctioned by his laws, that, in a matter of faith, or any ecclesiastical ordinance, he should judge who was not unsuited by office, nor disqualified by equity, for these are the words of the rescript.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:13
verses.text: That is, it was his desire that priests should judge concerning priests.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:14
verses.text: Moreover, if a bishop were accused of other matters also, and a question of character was to be enquired into, it was also his will that this should be reserved for the judgment of bishops.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:16
verses.text: Who, then, has answered your Clemency contumaciously? He who desires that you should be like your father, or he that wishes you to be unlike him? Unless, perhaps, the judgment of so great an Emperor seems to any persons of small account, whose faith has been proved by the constancy of his profession, and his wisdom declared by the continual improvement of the State.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:18
verses.text: When have you heard, most gracious Emperor, that laymen gave judgment concerning a bishop in a matter of faith? Are we so prostrate through the flattery of some as to be unmindful of the rights of the priesthood, and do I think that I can entrust to others what God has given me? If a bishop is to be taught by a layman, what will follow? Let the layman argue, and the bishop listen, let the bishop learn of the layman.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:19
verses.text: But undoubtedly, whether we go through the series of the holy Scriptures, or the times of old, who is there who can deny that, in a matter of faith,—in a matter I say of faith,—bishops are wont to judge of Christian emperors, not emperors of bishops.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:21
verses.text: You will, by the favour of God, attain to a riper age, and then you will judge what kind of bishop he is who subjects the rights of the priesthood to laymen.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:22
verses.text: Your father, by the favour of God a man of riper age, used to say: It is not my business to judge between bishops.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:23
verses.text: Your Clemency now says: I ought to judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:24
verses.text: And he, though baptized in Christ, thought himself unequal to the burden of such a judgment, does your Clemency, who have yet to earn for yourself the sacrament of baptism, arrogate to yourself a judgment concerning the faith, though ignorant of the sacrament of that faith?  6.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:25
verses.text: I can leave it to be imagined what sort of judges he will have chosen, since he is afraid to publish their names.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:26
verses.text: Let them simply come to the Church, if there are any to come; let them listen with the people, not for every one to sit as judge, but that each may examine his own disposition, and choose whom to follow.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:27
verses.text: The matter is concerning the bishop of that Church: if the people hear him and think that he has the best of the argument, let them follow him, I shall not be jealous.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:29
verses.text: I omit to mention that the people have themselves already given their judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:30
verses.text: I am silent as to the fact that they demanded of your father him whom they now have.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:31
verses.text: I am silent as to the promise of your father that if he who was chosen would undertake the bishopric there should be tranquillity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:32
verses.text: I acted on the faith of these promises.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:34
verses.text: But if he boasts himself of the approval of some foreigners, let him be bishop there from whence they are who think that he ought to receive the name of bishop.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:35
verses.text: For I neither recognize him as a bishop, nor know I whence he comes.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:37
verses.text: And how, O Emperor, are we to settle a matter on which you have already declared your judgment, and have even promulgated laws, so that it is not open to any one to judge otherwise? But when you laid down this law for others, you laid it down for yourself as well.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:38
verses.text: For the Emperor is the first to keep the laws which he passes.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:39
verses.text: Do you, then, wish me to try how those who are chosen as judges will either come, contrary to your decision, or at least excuse themselves, saying that they cannot act against so severe and so stringent a law of the Emperor?  10.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:40
verses.text: But this would be the act of one contumacious, not of one who knew his position.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:41
verses.text: See, O Emperor, you are already yourself partially rescinding your law, would that it were not partially but altogether! for I would not that your law should be set above the law of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:42
verses.text: The law of God has taught us what to follow; human laws cannot teach us this.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:43
verses.text: They usually extort a change from the fearful, but they cannot inspire faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:45
verses.text: Who, then, will there be, who when he reads that at one instant through so many provinces the order was given, that whoever acts against the Emperor shall be beheaded, that whoever does not give up the temple of God shall at once be put to death; who, say, is there who will be able either alone or with a few others to say to the Emperor: I do not approve of your law? Priests are not allowed to say this, are then laymen allowed? And shall he judge concerning the faith who either hopes for favour or is afraid of giving offence?  12.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:46
verses.text: Lastly, shall I myself choose laymen for judges, who, if they upheld the truth of their faith, would be either proscribed or put to death, as that law passed concerning the faith decrees? Shall I then expose these men either to denial of the truth or to punishment?  13.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:47
verses.text: Ambrose is not of sufficient importance to degrade the priesthood on his own account.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:48
verses.text: The life of one is not of so much value as the dignity of all priests, by whose advice I gave those directions, when they intimated that there might perchance be some heathen or Jew chosen by Auxentius, to whom I should give a triumph over Christ, if I entrusted to him a judgment concerning Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:49
verses.text: What else pleases them but to hear of some insult to Christ? What else can please them unless (which God forbid) the Godhead of Christ should be denied? Plainly they agree well with the Arian who says that Christ is a creature, which also heathen and Jews most readily acknowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:51
verses.text: This was decreed at the Synod of Ariminum, and rightly do I detest that council, following the rule of the Nicene Council, from which neither death nor the sword can detach me, which faith the father of your Clemency also, Theodosius, the most blessed Emperor, both approved and follows.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:52
verses.text: The Gauls hold this faith, and Spain, and keep it with the pious confession of the Divine Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:54
verses.text: If anything has to be discussed I have learnt to discuss it in church as those before me did.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:55
verses.text: If a conference is to be held concerning the faith, there ought to be a gathering of Bishops, as was done under Constantine, the Prince of august memory, who did not promulgate any laws beforehand, but left the decision to the Bishops.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:56
verses.text: This was done also under Constantius, Emperor of august memory, the heir of his father's dignity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:57
verses.text: But what began well ended otherwise, for the Bishops had at first subscribed an unadulterated confession of faith, but since some were desirous of deciding concerning the faith inside the palace, they managed that those decisions of the Bishops should be altered by fraud.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:58
verses.text: But they immediately recalled this perverted decision, and certainly the larger number at Ariminum approved the faith of the Nicene Council and condemned the Arian propositions.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:60
verses.text: If Auxentius appeals to a synod, in order to discuss points concerning the faith (although it is not necessary that so many Bishops should be troubled for the sake of one man, who, even if he were an angel from heaven, ought not to be preferred to the peace of the Church), when I hear that a synod is gathering, I, too, will not be wanting.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:61
verses.text: Repeal, then, the law if you wish for a disputation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:63
verses.text: I would have come, O Emperor, to your consistory, and have made these remarks in your presence, if either the Bishops or the people had allowed me, but they said that matters concerning the faith ought to be treated in the church, in presence of the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:65
verses.text: And I wish, O Emperor, that you had not given sentence that I should go into banishment whither I would.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:66
verses.text: I went out daily.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:67
verses.text: No one guarded me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:68
verses.text: You ought to have appointed me a place wherever you would, for I offered myself for anything.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:69
verses.text: But now the clergy say to me, "There is not much difference whether you voluntarily  leave the altar of Christ or betray it, for if you leave it you will betray it".

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:71
verses.text: And I wish it were clearly certain to me that the Church would by no means be given over to the Arians.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:72
verses.text: I would then willingly offer myself to the will of your piety.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:73
verses.text: But if I only am guilty of disturbance, why is there a command to invade all other churches? I would it were established that no one should trouble the churches, and then I could wish that whatever sentence seems good should be pronounced concerning me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:75
verses.text: Vouchsafe, then, O Emperor, to accept the reason for which I could not come to the consistory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:76
verses.text: I have never learned to appear in the consistory except on your behalf, and I am not able to dispute within the palace, who neither know nor wish to know the secrets of the palace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Letter XXI 1:78
verses.text: I, Ambrose, Bishop, offer this memorial to the most gracious Emperor, and most blessed Augustus Valentinian.
